title: KNOW YOUR RASPBERRIES - How to get a BUMPER crop from your homegrown raspberries

subtasks: Distinguishing between primocanes (new growth) and floricanes (second-year growth)
Pruning techniques for different raspberry varieties (summer-bearing, autumn-bearing, everbearing)
Proper fertilization methods, emphasizing foliar feeding
Maintaining optimal soil moisture and drainage
Ensuring adequate sunlight exposure
Selecting healthy primocanes for the following year's floricanes
Staking canes to support berry development and prevent breakage
Removing dead or weak floricanes

tasks.task: Managing raspberry growth through variety selection
subtasks: Choosing between summer-bearing, autumn-bearing, and everbearing raspberry varieties
Balancing harvest frequency with cane management
Checking for signs of water stress (leaf drooping, burning)
Preventing root rot in well-draining soil
Distinguish between primocanes and floricanes.
Identify variety (summer, autumn, everbearer) to know pruning method.
Responsive watering based on plant signals (leaf droop).
Select and maintain 3-5 strong primocanes per plant.
Stake primocanes for support and arranging in a vase shape.
Remove dead or overwintered floricanes.
Apply foliar feed due to leaf-absorption efficiency.
Ensure well-draining soil with organic matter to retain moisture.
Place plants in full sun (at least all day).
Look for signs of overwatering or underwatering from leaf condition.
Prune appropriately based on variety (when to cut autumn-bearing back, etc.)
For everbearing raspberries, retain both primocanes and floricanes for continuous harvesting.
Distinguish between primocanes (new growth) and floricanes (second-year growth)
Identify Raspberry variety (summer-bearing, autumn-bearing, everbearing) to determine pruning method
Respond to plant signals (e.g., drooping leaves) for watering
Select 3-5 strong primocanes per plant
Stake primocanes for support
Remove dead, overwintered floricanes
Apply foliar feed using leaves for nutrient absorption
Ensure well-draining soil with organic matter
Position plants in full sunlight all day
Check for signs of over/underwatering (e.g., drooping or burned leaves)
Prune appropriately based on variety (e.g., cutting autumn-bearing canes to ground in winter)
Consider different varieties for desired harvest times (summer, autumn, continuous)
